text:
S-X2
295. Wood, Hilda Henrietta (Mrs. Frederick William)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Hilda Wood, nee Wylie
Address: 427 5th Ave. North
Birthplace: Cheltenham, Glos. England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1918
Where did you set up housekeeping? On the farm, 7 miles from Raymond, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Cheltenham
For how many people did you prepare meals? Husband (and family later)
How far was it to your nearest store? 7 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Any time weather suitable
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Necessities such as flour, sugar, tea, sugar, dried fruit, butter, fresh meat was usually obtained from the butcher when we could afford it. Bread and cake sometimes bought from the store. Occasionally fresh fruit could be got.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? White Rose
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. bags and 50 lb. bags
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $2.85
How much did you use graham flour? Sometimes
Whole wheat flour? Sometimes, but always hard to get
Was flour milled locally? Yes, How far away? 7 miles What year? 1918
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 20¢ I believe
What other grain products did you use? Another receipt, brown breakfast flour
Cornmeal? No Whole Wheat? Sometimes Farina? Sometimes
Other? Rolled oats
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to us.

Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, Canada.

Name: ____________________________
Address: ____________________________
Birthplace: _________________________

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ______
Where did you set up housekeeping? _______________________________
Where had you been living before that? ____________________________
For how many people did you prepare meals? _______________________
How far was it to your nearest store? _______________________________
How often could a visit be made to the store? _______________________
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ____________

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ____________
In what quantities did you buy it? _________________________________
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ________
How much did you use graham flour? ______________________________
Whole wheat flour milled locally? _________________________________
Was flour milled locally? _________________________________
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ____________
What other grain products did you use? ____________________________
Cornmeal? _________________________________
Other? _________________________________
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? _______________________
How did you grind it? _________________________________
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs. bag or 50 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? About $2.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 5 lbs.

At what price? Cannot remember.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had our own cows.

Butter? Usually bought. Eggs? Usually bought.

What was the price of butter? About $2.50.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We could buy fresh fish sometimes. We raised chickens which we kept for winter. Once or twice we raised a few pigs so we could have pork in the spring.

How did you get fresh meat? We bought from the Raymond Butten.

How often did you get fresh meat? Sometimes we could get it from other farmers in winter time. We could buy a quarter of beef often.

How did you preserve meat? By canning.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized? About 1922 I believe (not sure).

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pheasant, quail, prairie chicken.

For how long? We could freeze them in winter time.

What part did fish play in the family diet? We could get salted white fish from the river. We would freeze and store it in winter time.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? All three.

Kinds? Salmon, perch, white fish, pike, trout, catfish.
3. SUGAR AND STARCHES

In what quantity did you buy sugar? [Blank]

What was the price for a ton point sack of sugar? [Blank]

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? [Blank]

At what price? [Blank]

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? [Blank]

Butter? [Blank]

That was the price of butter? [Blank]

Did you keep eggs for eating? [Blank]

Did you make butter? [Blank]

5. MEAT AND FISH

That was your meat supply in the early years? [Blank]

How often did you get fresh meat? [Blank]

Was there a "feed yard" in your neighborhood? [Blank]

Did you use game? [Blank]

For how long? [Blank]

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? [Blank]
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. At what price? About $1.75 per lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? About $.40.

What other beverages were used? Coffee, milk.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? About $4.00 per bu.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? Local grocer.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1911, Cabbage 1911, Carrots 1911, Onions 1911, Turnips 1911, Beets 1911.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? Not at all.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Monthly, 3-4 lbs. (bulk), sometimes by box.

What weight? 5 lbs.

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Local grocer sold them in bags.

What was the price of prunes? About 20¢ per 2 lbs.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

Peas? No. Corn? No. Beans? No. Saskatoons? Sometimes canned.

Other foods? No.

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1912.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1912.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1912.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

To what extent?

Did you make your own vinegar? No.
6. **BUYING**

What kind of tea did you buy?  
At what price?  
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground)  
Price?  
What other beverages did you buy?  

7. **VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS**

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you got up housekeeping?  
A bushel?  
Could you get potatoes at the store?  
Yes  
No  
Locally grown?  
That year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:  
Potatoes  
Cabbages  
Carrots  
Onions  
Turnips  
Beets  
Radishes  
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?  
How did you buy beans? (in bulk or by the box)?  
Monthly?  
Weekly?  
Occasionally?  
What weight?  
How did the grocer weigh? (per box)?  
Was the price of potatoes?  
That other dried fruit to add for use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. **PRESERVING**

In the early years did you preserve any foods by:  
Peas?  
Beans?  
Corn?  
Other foods?  
That year did you first preserve fruit by canning?  
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?  
That year did you first preserve meat by canning?  
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?  
To what extent?  
Did you make your own vinegar?
9. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                  | Year you first remember seeing it in the store | How was it sold? - In bulk, 10 lb., sack, can etc. | Ant. you usually bought at one time | Price of this amount |
|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------|---------------------|
| Soda biscuits         | 1910                                           | Usually 1 lb. 65¢ or 4 lb. 3½¢                   | 1 lb.                               | 15¢                 |
| Macaroni              | 1910                                           | 2 lb. 5¢                                         | 2 lb.                               | 2 lb. 3½¢           |

| Common salt           | 1910                                           |                                                 |                                     |                     |
| Lily white syrup      | 1910                                           | 2 lb. 2½ lb.                                     | 2 lb.                               | about 30¢ each      |
| Toilet soap           | 1910                                           | In cakes as apparent                             | 5 lb.                               | about 7¢ per cake   |
| Baking powder         | 1910                                           | In 1 or 5 lb. cans                               | 1 lb.                               | 25¢ per lb.         |
| Baking soda           | 1910                                           | 1 lb. pkt.                                       | 1 lb.                               | 15¢                 |
| Dried peas            | 1910                                           | no                                              | no                                  |                     |
| Dried corn            | 1910                                           | no                                              | no                                  |                     |
| Vinorar               | 1910                                           | We usually bought                                 | ½ gal. I forget price               |                     |

|                       |                                               | also pots of ¼ lb.                               | 5 lb.                               |                     |
| Rice                  | 1910                                           | 1 lb. or 5 lb.                                   | 1 lb.                               |                     |
| Currants              | 1910                                           | no                                              | no                                  |                     |
| Store jam - kinds?    | Pearl, plum etc.                                | 4 lb. cases                                      | 4 lb.                               | about 45¢ per can   |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | 1910 | By the pound                                     | 2-3 lb.                             | about 15¢ per lb.   |
| Vanilla               | 1910                                           | By small bottles                                 | about 15¢ oz.                       | 15¢                 |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Ashtabula

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes

Using starter? No

Using hops? No

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Crown of tartar? Sometimes

Did you make your own baking powder? No

Baked my own bread

| Currants              | 1910 | 1.00  |

| Vanilla               | 1910 | 1.00  |

10. Baking:
   - What type of yeast did you use?
   - Did you make yeast for your own use?
   - Using hops?
   - Did you buy baking powder?
   - Did you take your own baking soda?
   - Did you make your own bread?
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                        | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|-------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|

| Canned sardines             | 1911                                   | small tin about 1 lb.         | cheaper                                        |
| Other canned fish that appear early - give names | 1911                                   | small tin                      | cheaper in early days                           |

| Pearl tapioca               |                                        | Did not buy it                |                                                |
| Minato tapioca              |                                        |                               |                                                |
| Sago                        |                                        |                               |                                                |

| Icing sugar                 |                                        | 10¢ per lb. usually           | cheaper than                                    |

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...................................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ..............................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

I lived on the farm (homesteaded) for 7 years after coming to Canada. Raymond Park. The well water was used then. We had a pump put up. We moved then to Rockton. Tanks were used, but we also had water brought to our door by tank by Mr. Ward. This was in 1918. I have bought twice in rural schools a lot. Water mostly bought by tank or obtained from well, a communal well.
| Item                  | Approximate Price at the Time |
|-----------------------|------------------------------|
| Canned salmon         | 1911                         |
| Canned sardines       | 1911                         |
| Other canned fish    | 1911                         |
| Apples - fresh        | 1910                         |
| Apples - dried        | 1910                         |
| Lettuce               | 1910                         |
| Tomatoes - French     | 1910                         |
| Bananas               | 1910                         |
| Lemons                | 1910                         |
| Oranges               | 1910                         |
| Cornflakes            | 1910                         |
| Pearl tapioca         |                               |
| Minute tapioca        |                               |
| Sago                  |                               |
| Dates                 |                               |
| Walnuts               |                               |
| Icing sugar           |                               |

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

If so, how was this water from your house? (pail, barrel, tank)
12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ........................................... well

How far was this water from your home? .................................................. 3/4 mile

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...................................... by pail

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

I lived on the farm here until 1918, then moved to Park City. We had a pump but no well. Then we had a well but also no pump. We moved there in 1918.
12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ........................................... well .......................................................

How far was this water from your home? ........................................... a few yards ...........................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................................... by pail ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

I lived on the farm (homestead) for 7 years after coming to Canada at Raymond Park. The well water was used then. We had a pump put in. We moved there to Rockton. Taps were used - but not also had water brought to our door by tank by Mr. Ware. (This was in 1918-21)

I have taught twice in rural schools a lot. Water mostly brought by tank or obtained from well - a communal well.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Royal Crown

If you made your own, did you use lye? wood ashes?

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood and hard coal.

Where did you get your fuel? From Raymore. We also had some poplar wood and used our own farm.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Coal oil I first used about 1918—also electricity.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Yes, we used a large "Gem" cook stove—then a large home range.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? I think it came from Canada.

What year was it purchased? About 1905—6. Price? I don't know.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ... Tin, enamel, mostly... Aluminum

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ... China, enamel, earthenware, mostly...

When did you first see enamel ware? I forget, I think 1912 in Canada but I bought 2 or 3 white aluminum? About 1913—5. I think... except pie dishes (deep) from England.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap to make your own? If so, how much did you use?

If you used none, what kind of laundry soap did you purchase?

What did you use in the wash at home? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the wash at home? (Wood, kerosene, gas, electric)

Share any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you moved.

First started housekeeping, giving date where possible.

Next year first cook stove purchased? (Give date)

That year was it purchased? (Give date)

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (Glass, earthenware, wood, metal, other)

When did you first see annual rates? (Give date)

Aluminum? (Give date)
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?

If you made your own, did you use lye? (Give dates)

What kind(s) of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

That fuel did you use in an earthen stove? (Give dates)

There did you not your fuel? (Give dates)

15. ITEMS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? (Name and address)

That year was it purchased? (Give date)

That type of stove? (Give name)

Why, how, when, where, what, how much?

For preparing food? (chips, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see metal pans? (Give date)

Aluminum? (About 1912)
13. STAPLES

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If so, did you use Lysol? What kind of laundry soap did the grocer recommend?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the early days? Wood, charcoal, kerosene, oil, gas, electric?

15. TABLES OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or own hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake outdoors? By whom was your first cook stove made? Price? Date? For preparing food? (chili, stew, soup, etc.) What did you first see served? (steak, roast beef, other) Aluminum? About 1875-1900.
16. **Shopping and Cooking**

   Certain day changes which you recall in the newspaper and cookbooks received with the food you purchased (give dates here possible). Brown sugar, flour, and salt are used in early days. Bread - sometimes baked at home while living in town. Food will be hard to come by until in late spring.

3. **March 10th** - Very hungry from work and in town.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the date and list the names of the family members or names.

   Breakfast - milk, eggs, toast, bacon, and coffee.

   Lunch - sandwich, soup, and fruit.

   Dinner - roast beef, mashed potatoes, vegetables, and gravy.

   Supper - bread pudding, applesauce, and tea.

18. What did you serve for your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

   **Christmas Day** - Turkey, vegetables, stuffing, cranberry sauce, and mince pie.

   **December 25th** - Turkey, vegetables, stuffing, cranberry sauce, and mince pie.

   **December 26th** - Turkey, vegetables, stuffing, cranberry sauce, and mince pie.

   **December 27th** - Turkey, vegetables, stuffing, cranberry sauce, and mince pie.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods?

   **No** - we never suffered to such an extent. We always had plenty of flour and sugar, but we always had plenty of flour and sugar, potatoes, tea, and dried fruit.
16. What did you eat during the war? Give details.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the names of the family members who ate the meal.

18. Did you ever have to go without food? If so, how long?

19. Were you ever refused to almost starvation? Give details.

20. How did you manage to survive the war?
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the 
earliest days as compared with today. (Give as many details and dates 
as possible.)

21. Then did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead 
of fresh vegetables and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates 
as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries 
and securing foods in your earlier pioneer days in northern Canada. 
Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, profits lost or gained, shortages, etc., other details. Use back of 
page if more space needed.

The Quality Of Goods In The Farm Period

1910 - 1918 are quite good as I remember 
I also think we had a much 
lower level than today as far as prices 
were concerned. We have much 
more variety today 
we have had a new 
air so prohibition was hard to pick 
and choose here. I have heard of a new 
one "we could not afford sugar if we used 
days" I wish we could afford that we did 
not use it at the table.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the
   early days compared with today.

21. What did you do during the day? How did you spend your time?

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries
   and other foods in your area.

The quality of goods in the farm period

1910 - 1918 was quite good and generous.

It also shows us how much cheaper
lower priced meat today. We have much
better meat at present. We have much
more variety today but when we
were on prohibition we had a new
and choice menu. I have heard of early
days we could not afford sugar if we did
not want to deny ourselves at the table.
Oxford
